name: Identifying Stakeholders
what: This subtopic covers who the stakeholders of a business are and how they relate to the three levels of the business environment: macro, operating, and internal. A stakeholder is anyone who can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business.
why: Understanding who the stakeholders are is the foundation for managing business relationships effectively. Without knowing who has a stake in the business, managers cannot anticipate pressures, resolve conflicts, or build strategies for success.

items.title: I can define the term stakeholder in a business context
items.what: A stakeholder is any individual or group that can either affect or be affected by the operations of a business. Stakeholders exist at all levels of the business environment.
items.why: Being able to clearly define this term is essential for all further analysis of stakeholder interests, conflicts, and responsibilities.
items.example: Employees are stakeholders because their livelihoods depend on the business, and their performance directly affects business success.

items.title: I can identify internal environment stakeholders of a business
items.what: Internal stakeholders are those within the business over which it has control. These include owners (or shareholders), directors, managers, and employees.
items.why: Internal stakeholders are closest to the daily operations and decision-making of the business, making them critical to its functioning and culture.
items.example: In a company like Coles, internal stakeholders include the board of directors who set strategy, store managers who run individual locations, and the thousands of employees who serve customers daily.

items.title: I can identify operating environment stakeholders of a business
items.what: Operating environment stakeholders are immediately external to the business and interact closely with it. These include customers, suppliers, and competitors.
items.why: These stakeholders have a direct, regular impact on business operations, influencing revenue, costs, and competitive positioning.
items.example: For Woolworths, a key supplier of fresh produce is an operating environment stakeholder because their pricing, quality, and delivery reliability directly affect what Woolworths can offer customers.

items.title: I can identify macro environment stakeholders of a business
items.what: Macro environment stakeholders include the general community and society. These operate in the broad environment over which the business has no direct control.
items.why: Even though a business cannot control macro stakeholders, their expectations around ethics, employment, and environmental responsibility shape how the business must operate.
items.example: The local community near a factory is a macro stakeholder because they are affected by potential pollution, noise, and traffic from the business, even though they have no direct business relationship with it.

items.title: I can distinguish between the three levels of the business environment when classifying stakeholders
items.what: The three levels are the internal environment (within the business), the operating environment (immediately external with close interaction), and the macro environment (broad conditions beyond the business's control).
items.why: Classifying stakeholders by environment level helps managers understand the degree of control they have over each relationship and tailor their strategies accordingly.
items.example: A manager at a real estate agency would classify their sales agents as internal environment stakeholders, their property-listing clients as operating environment stakeholders, and the broader suburban community as macro environment stakeholders.
